item.title: 03: Site configuration
item.description: The following site configuration options are found in the config.toml file at the root of this Hugo site. Hugo variables A few Hugo-defined variables are included the example site’s config.toml file. You can find a complete list in the Hugo docs. Some key ones you’ll want to edit: baseURL = "/" title = "Hugo Ap√©ro" author = "Alison Hill" # set deliberately low for testing- choose your preferred number paginate = 5 At a minimum, change these values.

item.title: 04: Deploy your site
item.description: To preview your site locally, we have been using a blogdown function (or Add-in in RStudio): blogdown::serve_site() If you then push to GitHub, you are committing the source files (but not the built site) to GitHub. This is actually preferred, because we can teach Netlify how to build our site for us using the source files. Push to GitHub You can use the RStudio to push your current website project to GitHub.

item.title: 05: Section configuration
item.description: Hugo allows you to use a page’s front matter (written in yaml, toml, or json) to keep metadata attached to markdown files. The motto in Hugo is “everything is a page.” There are two sets of front matter for each content section. One set is for the section itself (/blog/_index.md), and the other for each page within a section, which consist of front matter plus content (/blog/my-blog-post/index.md). item.title: 06: Page configuration
item.description: Single pages in sections You have two options for where to place front matter for single pages. You can use the front matter of the page like /blog/my-blog-post/index.md, or you could use the cascade key in the section front matter like /blog/_index.md.
